div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: OCCIDENT v. ORIENT.
div.p: | The anti-Asiatic riots in the United States have suddenly assumed a shape which affects Great Britain far more seriously than did those of a few months ago. In the case of the anti Japanese agitation, our interest was only contingent; in that of the anti-Hindoo agitation which has just culminated in rioting at Bellingham, our interest is direct and unavoid able. A Hindoo is as much a British subject as an Englishman or Sootsman; whatever affects him injuriously in foreign countries is as much the concern of the British Government as if it offected injurioasly a man born in the British Isles instead of India. It is, therefore, a matter of peculiar importance to the Empire when the anti-Asiatie feeling in the West of America turns against the comparatively few Hindoos who dwell in the small frontier town near the northern boundary of the State of Washington. It seeins probable that the Indian Colony there is a relio of the unfortunate emigration movement which drew a

number of Indians to Canada some time ago. When they found that the climate was too severe for them, many, if not most, of the Indians went home of their own accord or had their passages paid for them; some, however, seem to have settled on the Pacifie slope. They were probably quiet and inoffensive, but industrious. At any rate, no credence need be given to the report spread by the anti-Asiatic agitators that white women were pashed into gutters and insalted on street-cars. A small community of new-comers, living precariously on sufferance in a foreign land, do not generally go out of their way to draw down the wrath of their hosts, and risk a possible lynching and certain banishment by attacking those who outnumber them by thousands to one.

- It so happens that the City Cogncil of Bellingham have acted in an unexpectedly creditable manner, in comparison with the course pursued by the Corporation of San Francisco. They have sworn in special officers to protect the strangers within their gates; but those strangers are already leaving for Vancouver. In British territory the Asiatic may not always be very welcome ; bat life, limb, and property are secure. It remains to be seen, however, whether the incident will end in this fashion. The feeling against the Orientals is still simmering in the Occident; it may boil over again at any moment. The Federal Government may profess themselves to be powerless to deal with a recaloitrant State in this matter; and ansatisfactory though that ples may be, it is not to be denied that the Americans can answer any protest which the British Government may make by a very effective "ta quoque." Much the same constitutional situation occurs in the British Empire, and the Imperial Government finds itself powerless to take any effective measures. Neither in Australia nor in South Africa are Asiatics desired, and small distinction is drawn in those Bountries under the Union Jack between Asiatics who are British subjects and Asia tios who are not. In both the colour bar is more power ful than the pass of Imperial citizenship. The Natal Restriction Act, for instance, which has become the foundation of all the Colonial exclusion laws now in force, does not specifically exclude Asiaties; it simply forbids the entry into the Colony of paupers or persons likely to become a public charge, idiots lunatios, diseased, immoral and criminal persons, and anybody who, when asked, fails to write in some European language application for admission to the Colony.

For all practical purposes such an Act hardly operates against any but Asiaties. And it is probably small consolation to the Hindoo to remember that he is exeluded from a British Colony, not as a British subject, but as an undesirable person whom the low places in the same category as lunatics and criminals. The poll-tax which prevails in other places is a more direct means of attaining the same end. The Asiatic is given to understand that he is not wanted in British Colonies; and this operates especially in countries where a white population rules an aboriginal coloured race. Here again, it is not very comforting to the civilised emigrant from India, who prides himself on his ancestors and on being a British subject, to remember that he is classed with the Kaffir or with those dying tribes of Australia which have not even a distinctive name of their own. The British Government have protested in the past against such exelusion laws, and have vetoed some of them on occasion; but neither their protest nor their veto has been of any effect. A sel-governing State of the Ernpire has, in practice, the power to say whom it will accept or refuse within its borders; and the admittedly impotent attitude of Lord Elgin in the latest case of British Indians in the Transvaal only tells again an oft-told tale. In these circumstances, it may be imagined how little force any representations from Mr. Bryce will have at Washington. The whole question of racial competition is of such appalling difficulty and complexity that one can do little more at present than grope towards a tentative solution, and deprecate any such inflammatory tactics as have been pursued on the Pacific slope of the United States. A definite issue is raised; unhappily, no definite answer can yet be given.

div.p: The "Amiral Miaonlis" a Greek training ship for marine cadets has just arrived at Port Said.

div.head: Israelite Fast.
div.p: To-morrow being the occasion of the great Israelite Fast, the Banks and Minet-el-Bassal market will be closed.

div.head: Journal Case
div.p: The procés against the native journals came before the Native Tribunal yesterday morning. Judgment was adjourned.

div.head: Cramophobia
div.p: Fathalla Waked, a chemist of Cairo, has been fined P.T. 500 by the Native Tribunal for playing a gramophone after mid-night.

div.head: Plague Bulletin
div.p: During the last twenty four hours two fresh cases have been reported at Alexandria and eight recoveries. There are at present eight cases under treatment.

div.head: Train Fatality.
div.p: A native, Ahmed Abdel-Gaffir. by name, was mounting & train in motion, when be slipped and fell on the rails. The train passed over his body, and death was immediate.

div.head: Assassin's Arresteret
div.p: The secret police of Cairo have arrested a certain Nicolas G. Koloris, who killed one of his parents in order to steal money. The assassin took to flight and was condemned to death by the local Native Tribonal on December 15 last. Koloris has been bronght to Alexandria under strong escort.

div.head: Public Works Ministry.
div.p: By a service order of the Public Works Ministry Abdel Rahman Effendi Aly has been appointed provisionally as engineer to the Zifta Circle of Irrigation at L.E. 17 per mensem. By the same order Youssef Effendi Pahmy Mohamed and Hassan Effendi Fouad have been appointed to the same circle at L.E. 18 per month

div.head: Sudden Death
div.p: The death is reported of a Jewish resident of Alexandria as occuring under somewhat exceptional circumstances. Resorting on Sunday night to a house of ill-fame, the man, whose age was 85 years, asked for a glass of water, and immediately after drinking the same he fell down in a fit and died before medical aid could be rendered.

div.head: Suspected Plague Cases
div.p: Three cases of suspected plague on board in-coming vessels have been disproved by observation during the last few days. On the arrival of the 8.8. "Sydney" in Alexandria the case of the death a child of seven years, in which plague had been diagnosed, was examined into and negatived, while other cases aboard the S.S. "Minieh” and 8.8. "Circassia" were also proved to have been wrongly diagnosed.

div.head: Tanzim Motor Destroyed.
div.p: Yesterday at about 3 p.m a tram ran into a Tanzim automobile, in the rue Vieux Caire which was leaving the Public Works building. The chauffeur escaped uninjured, but the motor was completely destroyed. A delay of 35 minutes was cansed while a shawish was being discovered! It is said that the Tramway Com pany intend to bring a case against the Tanzim owing to the great annoyance and loss caused by the stoppage.

div.head: At Petersburg
div.p: Russia also wants to assimilate the important discoveries of this century-not only in what concerns the military improvements but as well as in what appertains to the progress of the mind. The authorization has consequently been granted to the Berlitz School of Languages, Cairo 1 Bharia Kamel, Alexandria 12 rue Rosette--to open a branch at Petersburg. This new sehool which is already well frequented will certainly follow the example given by its 300 senior schools and like them will be patronized by the success based on gratitude and esteem. (Apvr.)

The 8.8. "Cyprian Prince" with passengers and general cargo left Manchester on the 13th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 29th September.
The 8.8. "Trojan Prince," with passengers and general cargo, left London on the 15th inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 1st October.
The 8.. "Indian Prince" left Antwerp on the 16th inst. and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 1st October.
The S.S. "Andalusian" left last night from Malta and is due here on the 20th inst, with passengers and mails.

div.head: CINEMATOGRAPE PATHE
div.p: Voici l'intéressant programme de cette se maine :

Séville et ses environs, grande scène de plein air ; la fée des roches ; le gendarme a du flair ; pochard -malgré lui; les débuts d'un patineur ; Discipline et Humanité, grande scène dramatique et réaliste ; un sculpteur express, scède à transformations ; diseuse de bonne aventure, seene de ger re; silhouette animée, scène à trucs; la Vengeance do Forgeron, grande scène dramatique en 60 tableaux ; au premier jour; et le Bombardement de Casablanca, scene absolument authentique prise sur le vif.

div.head: THE IRRAGATION SERVICE
div.p: REPORT FOR 1906.

div.head: THE NILE SUPPLY AND SEASON
div.p: In his report upon the irrigation service in Egypt and the Sudan for the year 1906 Sir William Garstin says :

The year 1906 showed a decided improvement, as regards river discharges, over its immediate predecessors. For seven years previous, the levels throughout the year had been persistently below the average, and in one case the river in summer fell to a point lower than any that had previously been recorded. Last year the maximum height registered was that of an average, but not of a good flood. At the end of 1905 the prospects for the following season were far from satisfactory, as the gauge readings at Wadi Halfa averaged some 40 centimetres below the normal river-level for that period of the year. Everything seemed to point to a continuance of the conditions that had so long ruled, and to indicate another year of poor supply. Early and abnormal rains, however, in the months of February and March brought a timely supply down the Blue Nile, apd materially changed the aspect of affairs -- converting what must otherwise have been a bad summer into a good one.

On May the 1st the Blue Nile at Roseires stood 1.13 metres above the average of previous years, and about this time the Sobat commenced to rise. Throughout the month in question the increase in both rivers was insig. nificant, but in June the levels of the Blue Nile rose rapidly. The rise in the Sobat also continued, but at a normal rate. These increases in the south did not, however, produce a similar effect in the north. From the commencement of May the river-levels at Wadi Halfa commenced to fall. This drop continued until the middle of June, when the effect of the annual steady rise began to make itself apparent. This rise, therefore, as regards Egypt was a late one, and until the middle of July was very slow. Subsequent to this last date, the increase was normal, and the rise of the river was continuous until the 18th of Sep tember, when the maximum height of 15 pics 20 kirats was registered upon the Aswan gauge. The fall of the river was also normal, and at the end of 1906 the levels at Wadi-Halfa were better than had been the case, at that season, in any one of the seven preceding years. Mr. Webb describes the measures taken for ensuring the effective distribution of water throughout the year, so I will not further allude to them. I must, however, say some thing about the effective manner in which he, and his staff, regulated and controlled the water stored in the Aswan Reservoir.

div.head: THE NILE RESERVOIR
div.p: The regulation of the dam sluices is a most intricate business, demanding continual care and study of the river to the south. The sluices last year were so skilfully manipulated that the levels of the river downstream of the dam mere steadily increased, as the summer advaneed, so as to correspond with and meet the increase in the demand for water in the north. The daily amount added to the river from the reservoir varied from six to twenty millions of cubic metres. It is difficult to speak too highly of the work here done by Mr. Maodonald, and his assistant, Mr. Cooper. Throughout the summer months, thanks to their labours, as the demand in Egypt increased, there was always more water forthcoming with which to meet it. Until the period of severe pressure (which occurs annually in July, just before the arrival of the flood) arose, water was plentiful every where, and the distribution gave but little tronble.

div.head: DEATH OF MR. DENMEN J.P.
div.p: We regret to record the death of Mr. T.W. Denman, J.P., which occurred recently at Retford, and we offer to his family and relations our sincere condolences. The Denman family, of wbom members have been residents in Egypt for several years, have been land owners in West and East Retford and neigh. bourhood for some hundred years. One of the family, Nicolas Denman of East Retford - whose old timbered house stood on or near the side of the national infants school, Grove Street, for about 300 years-married secondly Anne, daughter of Humphrey Herey, Esq. and sister of Sir John Hercy, Grove Hall, who at her brother's death, succeeded to the manor of West Retford, where they afterwards resided Her descendant was Anne Denman, who it is stated was the grandmother of two Queens of England —Queen Mary II and Queen Annewhile her sister Barbara married Edward Darrel Esq., of Horkstowe Manor, Lincolnshire.

Of their five sons the youngest and sole survivor was John Darrel, B.A., M.D., who dying childless, founded the noble charity of the Holy Trinity, West Retford. Thus Mr. Thomas William Denman was a collateral descendant of the original Dennan family as well as of the founder of the above named institution. Mr. Denman was proprietor in West Retford of some of the original lands, which were descended from his ancestor. He acted as solicitor to the Trinity "Hospital estate, and clerk to the Church and Poor Fond in West Retford.

div.head: Source of wealth
div.p: Many other things have contributed to the sound economic condition of Egypt. The adjective "economio” implies not merely that which pertains to the regulation of a country's management, but denotes equally freedom from wastefulness and extravagance. I need not dwell on the regularity and the reforms introduced, for they are known to all who have followed Lord Cromer's brilliant carcor, nor need I refer in great detail to the excellence of the financial system now. 80 firmly establis. hed, yet it is useful to point out that the latest Trade and Customs retums show a higher total than any ever previously attained, the total value of merchandise imported and exported in 1906 amounting to £48,888,000, as against less than half that sum in 1896. The revenue of Egypt has Nkewise steadily expanded - during the last five years at an average annual rate of £553,900 from £9,675,000 in 1887 to £15,374,000 in 1906. There is as well a sum of over elever millions sterling standing to the credit of the reserve fund, while the total amount of the Egyptian debt now in the hands of the public is but £87,416,000, and the interest charge borne by the taxpayers but £3,368,000, as compared with £96,457,000 and £4,268,000 in 1883, when the British first occupied the country and began their beneficent work of reform. And this result has been achieved notwithstanding progressive and very considerable reductions in taxation. It is noteworthy also that with the country's prosperity the population has increased from 6,814,000 in 1882 to 9,734,000 in 1897 (the date of the last census), and that it now approximates in the Delta provinces to 650 inhabitants to every square mile, or donble the estimated density of population in the United Kingdom. Labour is consequently abundant and continues cheap, while the Egyptian labourers are remarkable for their vigour and industry.

If in the foregoing preliminary pages I have refrained from giving statistical tables in support of the several assertions of fact. I have done so not because there is insufficient material from which to compile them, but rather because I have desired by a simple olear and cogent statement, not unduly burdened with figures, to disabuse the public mind of any possibly existing, though latent, impression that the recent Alexandria Bourse troubles reflect any semblance of unsoundness in the State. The facts I have inarshalled should dispel once and for all any lingering mists of doubt on this score, and baving thus cleared the ground I will proceed to show why I hold that a golden opportunity now exists in Egypt for the bona fide British investor, and I shall venture to indicate, quoting chapter and verse for my beliefs, certain safe investments.

To the far sighted the recent Bourse troubles will appear but a blessing in disguise. Not only was a larger quantity of shares placed last winter on the Alexandria market than the members of the European colonies in Egypt could absorb, but practically no assistance was forthcoming from the numbers of wealthy natives, for these gentlemen limit themselves almost entirely, when they do invest their sav. ings, to the purchase of agricultural lands. Not having sufficient ready-money capital, European purchasers of the new shares multiplied their holdings by having recourse to the old expedient of borrowing from their bankers, depositing as cover first their gilt | edged bearer securities-e.g., National, and Agricultural, Bank of Egypt shares--and final ly, as collateral cover, their newly-purchased shares. Seeing that the spirit of speculation was abroad, and that the concurrent and extraordinary boom in building plots must sooner or later, bring disaster to many, the principal Banks were at first chary of lending any but nominal sums on shares in the new companies, and finally refused altogether to lend anything at all on them. Driven into a corner when a few local failures caused the speculative bubble to burst, operators were not only frequently unable to pay off their loans, or provide fresh marginal cover, but in many cases found them selves saddled with lines of new shares (to say nothing of building lands)which had becomeprao tically, though but temporarily, unmarketable Thus they were constrained to allow the Banks to protect themselves by selling the securities deposited with them as guarantee for advances and, as sound shares like those of the National Bank of Egypt and of the Agricultural Bank were chief among the securities readily saleable, the consequence was that these highclass shares were thrown in large numbers on The market, with the inevitable result that National Banks tell from 281, at which figure they stood at the beginning of the present year to below £17, while Agrionltural Banks nenoted from £10 to 77. And it is noteworthy that the fall was aggravated by many of the shares be ing sold in Paris at the time when that Bourse was already depressed on account of the serious disturbances among the wine-growers in the extreme south of France. The financial position in Egypt thus became almost unique scarcity (of money) in the midst of plentywondrons prosperity and yet dearth of funds. (To be continued.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Moe Perry, under-secretary to the Public Works department, will leave for Europe on the 20 inst.
M. Scotidis has left Athens for Smyrna, where he will stay for a short time.
The Rev. J.H. Molesworth, M.A. Chaplain of All Saints Cairo, arrived on September 16 and is residing at present at Rossmore House.
Socrate Bey Spiro, general secretary of the Porta and Light Administration, is expected here in a few days.

A marriage has been arranged, and will shortly take place, between Francis Hubert Manley of Spofforth Hall, Yorks, son of the late George Manley, of Spofforth, and Gladys, only child of Sir Alfred Moloney, K.C.M.G., J.P., late Governor of Trinidad, now of Cefntilla Court, Usk, Monmouthshire, and the late Constance Lady Moloney.

The marriage took place yesterday of Me. Giuseppe Volpini, Advooste at the Court of Appeal, to Miss Rachel Guttieres Pegna, daughter of Mr. Albert Guttieres Pegna, a partner of the well-known firm G. Marons and Company

Mr. Georges M. Mobayed, son of Mr. Michel Móbayed, a prominent nember of the Syrian community of Alexandrix, returned this morning after a brilliant completion of his course of studies at the Crystal Palace School of Engineering, where he has been awarded the certificate of honour for six certificates obtained in the school course.

Among those who arrived this morning by the M.M mail boat were Mr. Durand, Captain Percival, Countess Zizinia, Dr. Fonquet, Mr. Macintyre, Mr. and Mrs. Bepedueci, Mr. Papa zian, Mr. Sheldrick, Mr. Lebland, and Mrs. Charlton.

div.head: THE "OLIVEMOOR."
div.p: The weather conditions are to-day considerably more favourable to the salvage operations, and the pump, the breakage of which necessitated the salvage steamer's return to harbour the night before last, having been repaired, operations are now being continued withont interruption. This morning seventy men were sent off to the wrecked vessel to jettison cargo, and on their arrival they immediately commenced throwing overboard general cargo, including cases of whiskey, firebrieks, coal, etc., etc. It is considered that, should the present favourable conditions continne, the vessel will be got off the rocks during the course of Thursday. The wind is now blowing chiefly from the north, the sen is calm, and the swell bas subsided considerably.

div.head: SHIP BUILDING IN EGYPT
div.p: Yesterday morning the first of the barges built by the Khedivial Mail Steamship, and Graving Dooks Company, Ltd., to the order of the Salt and Soda Company, Ltd., was launch ed trom the Khedivial Company's shipbuilding 1 yard at Alexandria, the launch being most Successfully performed in the presence of several interested onlookers. The entire work of construction and fitting of these barges, which have a length of 180 feet and an average speed of eight to nine knots an hour, is being done by the Khodirial Mail Company, and the barge launched yesterday gave amplo evidence of the excellence and thoroughness of the work. The "Salt," by which name the barge is to be known, will be ready for use in about four weeks' time, and yesterday afternoon the company commenced work upon her sister vessel the "Soda," which will be ready for launching in abont six weeks. After the launch the comIpany adjourned to the 8.8. "Osmanieh" where refreshments were served and the success of the “Salt" was toasted with unanimous oordiality. QUAIL SHOOTING ACCIDENT.

div.head: QUAIL SHOOTING ACCIDENT
div.p: We are sorry to learn, that Professor L. Poggetti, director of the Italian school, was badly injured while quail-shooting with a party of friends at Aboukir on Sunday afternoon. Mr. Poggetti and a friend were outside the cirole of shooters with the object of pioking off quail missed by other guns, the former crouching behind a heap of stories. Observing a qual flying low Mr. Poggetti rose to fire, but his companion brought dowh the bird before he could shoot, and Mr. Poggetti received a part of the charge full in the face. The damaging shot bad been fired from a distattee of only 15 to 20 yards, and infliotod considerable injury on Mr. Poggetti in left ey being badly affected. First aid was rendered at the house of Mr. Eynaud and Mr. Poggatti was afterwands conveyed to his own hom where he was attended by Dr. Borghi and Dr. Danaprindie. It is feared that the professor will lose the sight of his left eye.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB
div.p: We are desired by the honorary secretary of the Alexandria Swimming Club to remind our readers that the fifth annual aqustio sports of the club will be held on Saturday, the 12th of October, at Gabbary. The entries for the various events promise to be even more numerous than last year, and a record success is guaranteed by the energy displayed by the hon. secretary and the committee in the organisation of the meeting.

Members who have not as yet sent in their entry fortas-should do so at once and should also pot in an appearance, at the baths on Saturday or Sunday next, at any time from 3.30 p.m., for the purpose of having their times taken. Non-members desiring to compete in the sports, will kindly communicate with the Hon. See on or böföre Saturday next the 21st inst. Amongst other events the following will take place 60 yards Senior Handicap for “Sirdar" medal Senior and Junior Diving Championship, Juniors Race, Veterans Race and a 300 yards Invitation Team Race between the following-- Alexandria Rowing Club, Club International Canottieri, Club Nantique Français Deutscher Sportverein, Polo Mateh, Tag-of-War, Planging Championship, Walking the Pole, in fancy costume, Obstacle Race, Blindfold Race, Cock fighting
A special prize will be presented by the club to the member producing the six best photographic snapshots of the sports.

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: INCAPABLES Y. INCOMPETENTS. (FROM A CORRESPONDENT.)

A match between the above mentioned teams took place on the A.C.C. ground on Friday afternoon. The Incapables were suitably led by Mt. H. P. Carver while a natural course of selection devolved the captainey, of the Incompetents op Mr. Leslie Reid. The Inanpa bles won the toss and made bat a fooble display until the arrival of Carver Bros, who made the ball spin as merrily as they usually do the cotton, until finally canght out by the Finance Department

The Incompetents fulfilled the hopes of their sponsors until the arrival of Mr. R Barnard on the scene, who capably seeonded by Capt. Potts succeeded in all but putting matters on an even keel, Mr. Barand gave an astonishing ly dashing display to the tone of 61 compiled in less than half an hour.

The fact remains that the fortune of the Incapables was remarkable in winning this match against the exceptional bowling of Messrs D. Morice and L. Reid ably supported by the fielding of Messrs. Etherington Smith, and Borton. Messrs. Leslie, Beid, and Monica were at home before, during and after the match to their numetons friends and admirers, who spends most enjoyable afternoon

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Ce matin le marché a débuté ayeg berrcoup d'animation, pour se calmer un peu plus tard et finir terne, mais assez soutenu. Les valeurs dirigeantes ont été complètement délaisades, au profit de quelquesautres d'ordre, secondaire parmi lesquelles figurent au premier rang.. par ordre d'importance dans les transactions, la Delta Land, les Estatės, rurbaine et les Ritz, Hotels. Beaucoup de bruit, en somme, pour. peu de chose. C'est le Caite qui vend, comme cela ressort assez clairement du fait que ce sont les arbitragiktek qui travaillent et que la tenue da marché dans la capitale a été mapifestement plus faible qu'ici au cours de ces dernières séances. Sur notre place il y effort général pour maintenit les cours. tendance est ideoise.

Parmi les valeurs dirigeantes, la National Bank flbeltit encore de 20 3/16 20 1/8; la Privilégiée Delta Light reste à 9 11/16 vendeurs, mais la Dividende s'inscrit en nouvelle baisse d'une demi-live * 7 1/2 ; quant a lohi gation Orédit Poncier, l'offre qui suit ordinaire, ment le tirage du 16, ramène le prix de 299 297 pour l'ancienne et de 253 à 252 pour la nouvelle.

En recut également les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie de 149 1/2X142 vendeurs et la Land Bank de 7 3/16 a 7 1/8, tandis que les Lots Turcs progressent de 158 160, les Nungovich Hotels de 18 8/4 à 13 15/16, et l'Urbaine de 8 1/82 à 8 1/16. Le Banco di Roma se consolide # 104 1/2-105. 19

Les fluotuations ne sont pas moins inégales sur les titres de moindre envergure : ainsi la Salt and Soda s'avance de 18 1 18/3, 1. Delia Land de 1 5/8 #1 21/32 acheteurs et les Rita Hotels de 17/324 9/16, tandis que le fonda teur United rétrograde de 13/4 à 1 28/32, l'Aboukir de 27/6 * 27/8, la Building Lands de 2 1/82 à 2, et les Estates de 21/32 1 vendeurs.
Rien à signaler sur le reste de la cote hi comme transactions, ni comn e variations.

A la nouvelle enchère publique de ce matin, 100 Industrial and Building (Karam) ont été. achetés au prix de 28/64 et 70 Aboukit vendus à 27/3. Il s'agit encore d'une exécution ordon née à l'encontre de la Bonrse and Banking,

On assure que le marché x terme n'est pas près d'etre rétabk. Nombre de courtiers ayant encore des différences & payer, les antres atten dent évidemment d'être regtés pour consentir de nouveaux crédits et traiter des affaires 1 terme. C'est tout juste, parait-il, l'il y a soft samment de eonfiance réciproque pour traite comptant. La crise se trouve ainsi paral également le marché 1 terme "sur leqne tablait surtout pour une reprise.
Demain étant jour de chômage pour la corbeille des valeurs à l'occasion du grand Jeline Israélite, notre prochain bulletin ne pataltra que jeudi 19 courant.
Modifications in Poetal Arrangements consequent on the International Congress at Rome in 1896, which come into-force on the 1st October next.

div.head: LETTERS
div.p: The tax on letters originating in Egypt and the Sudan for Abroad will be:
1. Five million for every 20 grammes, or fraction thereof for Great Britain and Ireland and all British Colonies, Possessions and Protecterats with the exception of Newfoundland.
2. Five milliemes for every 20 grammes,or fraction thereof Italy, Eritrea and Benadir.
3. Ten missiles for the first 20 grammes and 6 milliemes for every extra 20 grammes for all Countries in the Postal Union not mentioned in Paragraphs 1 and 2
4. Ten milliemes for every 20 grammes, or fraction therof for Countires not in the Postal Union, viz :--Abyssinia, China (Interior) Afghanistan, New Hebrider, North East and North West Rhodesia.

div.head: POST-CARDS
div.p: Cards bearing the inscription "POST CARD" will be in the same category as "printed matter" provided that they fufil the condities laid down for such matter. Shold they, however, not fulfil these condities they will be considered as ordinary Post Cards and treated as such, otherwise, according to the regulations in force for Post Cards, they will be taxed as letters.

div.head: BUSINESS PAPERS & SAMPLES
div.p: Letter will post carde which have attained their primary object will be considered as commercial papers. Single keys, french cut flowers, tubes of serum and pathologic articles rendered inocuons by treatment or packing will be considered as samples

div.head: REPLY COUPONS
div.p: Reply coupons will enable the sender of a letter to transmit the cost of reply to the addressess. These reply coupons will be sold at 11 milliemes each.

These coupons can be exchanged in all Countries to which this Service extends for cash or postage stamps to the value of 25 Centimes. Information as to the Countries which are admitted to this Service can be obtained from any post office

div.head: FOREIGN MONEY ORDERS
div.p: The tax on Foreign Money Orders will be as follows:--
1. Ten milliemes for every or frutice there for Money Orders addressed to Great Brital and Ireland, all British Colonies, Pressions al Protectomster, and Ramis

2. Ten milliemes for every £:2 or fraction plus 5 milliems as a supplementary charge for exchange (total 15 milliemes) for Money Orders addressed to those Countries included in the International Convention

div.head: INSCRIPTIONS ON MONEY ORDERS.
div.p: Money Orders which bear an inscription written in pencil will not be acceptet

div.head: PARCELS
div.p: The tax on paroels not exceeding 1 Kilo: in weight will be reduced for certain Countries.
1. Parcels of which the wires are written in pencil will not be accepted for transmission

2. Parcels for abroad must be packed in some manner as to ensure the safety and preservation of the contente during transport. They must also be sealed with war, lead or some such substance, which seals must bear the imprint of some special design.
Customs declarations must accompany all parcels for abroad and must show the exact value of the contents of such parcels in order to facilitate the, collection of export and quay dues (if any).

Communications relative to parsels sent may be written on Despath Notes. This facility however does not extend to Despatch Notes of parcels addressed to Great Britain and, Irland and British Colonies, with the exeption of British India.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENT OP RECEIPT AND PAYMENT
div.p: The sender of registered or insured article a parcel or a money order will be able to obtain an Acknowledgement of Receipt by the addreśsee from the Post Office of payment of 10 milliemes at the time of posting

div.head: OTHER SERVICES
div.p: Notice is also given to the effect that the following services, which have not undergone much alterations by the Postal Congress, are undertaken by the Post Office.
By means of this service the contents at letters and boxes can be insured according to their value, with a maximum of 10,000 francs

The Post Office will undertake to present any bill, draft etc. to a debtor for collection of the amount. In case this cannot be obtained however no action will be taken by the Post Office against the person.

Subscriptions for newspapers published in Egypt and the Sudan as well as Austria-Hungary, Belgium, Great Britain and Ireland, Germany, Italy, Switzerland and the United States of America, can be taken out at the Post Office

4. Identity CertificatesIn order to minimise the difficulties often experienced by the Public in obtaining postal matter or money orders addressed to them, identity certificates can be obtained from Post Office at the rate of 20 milliemes each.
These certificates hold good for the following Countries :--
Argentine Republic, Algeria, Bulgaria, Chili, France, Greece, Italy, Luxemburg, Mexico, Portugal and Portugese Colonies, Roumania, Switzerland, Tunis, Turkey and Venezuela
General Pont Ofice.
30913-3*-1 Egypt, 16th September 1907.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication un emplacement gazonné dans le Grand Jardin Nousha de la superficie de 3 feddans environ pour café pablic et restaurant
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau des Pares et Plantations où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés
Les offres devront être adresses sous pli cacheté Monsieur le Vice President de la Municipalité avant le ler Octobre prochain.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: Soumission pour la location de café au Grand Jardin Nouzha
Le cautionnement préva au cahier des charges, devra être versé an Service de la Comptabilité générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le ler Octobre de 9 h. à midi.
Toate offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions cids Mr Snartte
Si les offres ne sont satisfaisantes, la Municipalité n'est pas tenue de les accepter.
Alexandrie le 14/9/07.

div.head: THE CASABLANCA SITUATION.
div.p: ARREST OF UJDA NOTABLES.
SULTAN LEAVES FOR RABAT.
Four Ujda notables have been arrested and brought to Lallamarnia. They are charged with carrying on an anti-French propaganda among the tribes.(Reuter)
The French balloon ascended yesterday. The entire country was reported to be clear of Arabs. (Reuter)

Everything is quiet. The troops are resting. Two camps, Titmellel and Merchich, are reported at 25 kilometres to the south. If the peace emissaries have not arrived by noon to-day, Kasba Fedala will be bombarded, and General Drude's operations will be vigoronsly recommenced. (Havas)
The Mehallas are now camped beyond the reach of cannon. The Governor of the town yesterday paid a visit of courtesy to General Drnde. (Havas)
The Moorish Minister of War bas agreed to organise police without delay, as provided and stipulated by the Algeciras Act. The Sultan Abdul Aziz left Suez on the 12th for Rabat. (Havas)
The Sultan has left Fez for Rabat where he is expected to arrive on 21st instant. It is reported that Mulay Hafid is also going to Rabat with 30,000 followers.
General Drude reports that a prolonged armistice of 24 hours has been granted at the request of the tribesmen, the majority of whom are in favour of peace. (Reuter)

div.head: THE "STANDART WRECK.
div.p: SEVERE PRESS CENSURE..

The Press attacks the naval administration for the stranding of the "Standart." The “Slove" declares the incident to be worse than the Tshushima one. It stigmatizes the administration's ignorance of home waters as criminal. (Reuter)

div.head: ENGLAND IN EGYPT.
div.p: APPEAL TO LIBERAL PARTY.

Mustapha Pasha Kamel, in a letter addressed to Sir H. Campbell Bannerman, declares that 25 years have passed since England promised to evacuate Egypt. The Liberal party in England must decide whether Egypt's independence is to come with Liberal help or without (Reuter)

div.head: THE WELLMAN EXPEDITION.
div.p: ABANDONED FOR A YEAR.
NEW YORK, September 14. Mr. Wellman's airship has been rescued in a glacier intact. The expedition has been abandoned for a year. (Reuter)

div.head: SIR H. MACLEAN.
div.p: RAISULI'S CONDITIONS.

More cheerful letters have been received from Sir H. Maclean stating that He has been allowed certain comforts. El Raisu'i's demands as presented to Great Britain are still impossible, but he is expected to rapidly moderate them. (Reuter)

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE
div.p: THE "TIMES" CENSURES

The "Times" comments on the danger of the Hagne Conference seeking to hide failure by nominally sanctioning a number of showy ill-considered propositions in order to impress an uninstructed public. It cites the case of the Prize Court and says that the reason for which Russia and Japan provisionally withheld their assent was weighty. It urges that England should follow the example of her sagacious ally Japan and take time to minutely study the Prize Court scheme before committing herself. (Reuter)

div.head: GREECE AND TURKEY.
div.p: DRAMA PATRIARCHATE RECALLED
In consequence of the urgent and frequent representations of the Porte, the Patriarchate bas recalled the Metropolitan of Drama who, it is alleged, was implicated in the Greek band movement.(Reuter)
The Abyssinian mission has arrived bere from Dresden.(Reuter)
The Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine bas presented a medal to Professor Looss of Cairo.(Reuter)
The ex-Grand Vizier, Mushir-el-Dowleh, is dead. (Reuter)
A councilorder has been gazetted establishing a legislative council for Cyprus, to be composed of 12 elective and 6 non elective members. (Reuter)
The Royal Irish Yacht Club has challenged the American Cup on behalf of Sir T. Lipton, for September 1908.(Reuter)

President Fallieres has reprieved the mur. derer Soleilland in spite of the popular clamour for his execution. This signifies the abolition of the death penalty in France Police are guarding the Elysée fearing a hostile demonstration. (Reuter)
A Quebec to Boston express has collided with a goods train : 17 persons have been killed and 40 injured. (Reuter)
Georgiades Effendi, the new Governor, has arrived here. He had a cool reception. (Reuter)
The match between the rest of England and Notts at Oval was drawn. (Reuter)

div.head: THE LEBANON EXPERIMENT
div.p: The special correspondent to the Times" writes from Beyrout as follows:--

The nomination of Yusuf Pasha to the Governorship of the Lebanon has not been received with any great enthusiasm in "the Mountain." The fear that the new Governor wonld follow the pro-elerical policy of his father, Franco Nasri Pasha, who governed the Lebanon from 1868 to 1873, had already provoked a demonstration of over 1,500 anti-clericals from the Maronite district of Kesrawan, with a few Druses who, on July 3, appeared in Beirut, and begged the Vali to transmit a petition to the Porte protesting against his appointment. It is quite possible that the petition never reached the Porte; but, however vain their protest, the anti-clericals of what was till recently the most bigoted district in the Maronite territory had at least the satisfaction of showing Beirut that their strength, sedulously minimized by the clergy, was numerically greater than their opponents had dared to admit. Other sections of the population regarded with some anxiety. the appointment of the son of a former Governor, connected by marriage with Naoum Pasha, who preceded the late Muzaffer Pasha as Governor of the province, arguing that the new Mutesarrif was not unlikely to be influenced by the supporters of his father and Naonm Pasha in the appointment and dismissal of functionaries, from the point of view of the numerous placehunters of the Lebanon, the most important of the prerogatives of the Governor of "the Mountain."

The future will show how far these apprehensions are well grounded ; meanwhile Yusuf Pasha will require greater abilities than those with which he is credited, even by his supporters, if he is to make a firm stand against the intrigues of families and factions and the growth of political corruption, which proved too strong for his predecessor. For Muzaffer Pasha's administration this much may be claimed---namely, that it equitably maintained the balance between the various religious secta, each of which was, and is, only too ready to take offence at the slightest encroachment, real or fancied, on its rights as guaranteed by the Organic Law of 1861. Otherwise, it was unsuccessful ; Liberal views and good intentions, personal integrity, tact, and kindliness could not atone for the fatal weakness of will that made the late Governor the pappet of intrigues local, Consular, and domestic and disappointed all who had believed that his early promises of administrative reform would be carried into effect. But whatever may have been urged against Muzaffer Pasha's administation, what ever may be urged in the future against that of Yusuf Pasha, it must be admitted that the position of the Governor of the Lebanon has become far from enviable. Though, perhaps, the most independent of Ottoman officials during his term of office, he is none the less compelled, in view of his eventual return to Constantinople, to avoid all action that may ruffle the susceptibilities or arouse the suspicions of the Sultan. The Great Powers of Europe' through their representatives at Beirut and Constantinople, take a more or less active interest in bis administration ; religious rival ries, the intrigues of local notables and of the administrative council, an antiquated Constitution, and an illogical system of local finance hamper his every action. He is, in short, condemned to carry out a most difficult task with the aid of obsolete machinery and with the certainty of interference from without and within.

It may be urged that this is a somewhat cavalier criticism of the results of the experiment of 1860, that since the interference of Europe the Lebanon has enjoyed complete immunity from the disturbances that are endemic in other provinces of the Ottoman Empire, that the Lebanese are themselves mainly to blame for the growing disorganization of the administration, or that, given a strong Governor of the type of Rustem Pasha, all would once more go well in the Mountain." Before reply. ing to these objections it is necessary to give a brief sketch of the physical and social condi. tions of the province, as far as they have any bearing upon local politics, and of its Con stitution according to the modified Organic Law ot 1864.
“THE MOUNTAIN” AND ITS PEOPLE

The province of Lebanon, as defined by the protocols of 1861 and 1864, is not contermin ons with the mountain range of that name. It may be roughly described as a strip of mount ainous country, bounded on the east by the watershed and on the west by the Mediterra nean, averaging some 25 miles in breadth, and extending some 40 miles north ard 80 miles south of Beirut, which, with the towns of Tripoli and Sidon, is under direct Ottoman administration. On the eastern slope of the central range of the Lebanon the town and part of the district of Zahleh belong to the province, as does the isolated village of Hurmil, 30 miles northwest of Baalbeck. Except in the neighbour hood of Beirut and in part of the district of Kūra immediately south of Tripoli, the country is simply a succession of stony ridges, projecting westward like ribs from the backbone of the central chain and separated from one another by deep and often precipitous ravines. Save in the low-lying areas that have been mentioned, the country is naturally little suited to agriculture, the whole of the corn crop, planted in the stoniest of soils, being insufficient to supply the needs of the population of the province for three months. The plodding industry of the pesants has covered the billsides with terraces, on which mulberries, vines, and a few other fruits are grown, and sericulture is now the principal, and in many districts almost the only, occapation of the people, the bulk of the ooooons, waste silk, and

silk thread exported, to the amount of nearly 25,000 bales during the last three years, from Beirut and Tripoli coming from the Lebanon villagos. Some 20 silk spinning mills, few of which employ more than 60 persons, are at work mainly in the central districts of the province. Vines are very generally grown, and some very good wine is manufactured in the neighbourhood of Zahleh. Sheep and goats are fairly numerous, and the latter most destructive to the soanty remnants of the forests which once covered the mountains. Minerals may exist in paying quantities within certain areas, but on this point nothing appears to be definitely known.

The whole configuration of the country makes for political disunion. A village is often nearly a day's journey from its vis-à-vis on the next ridge or on the next but one, only four or five miles away as the crow flies, bat separated by precipitous gorges hundreds of feet deep, and perhaps eight or ten miles in length. Religion, here as elsewhere in the Ottoman Empire, the principal cause of political division, has aided nature in accentuating the differences between the various sections of what seems to have been originally a fairly homogeneous population. There are certainly two or three general racial types that may be found, at times in the same family, all over Syria; but it is equally certain that some Europeans and many natives who possess a thorough knowledge of the country and its people can usually distinguish between a Maronite and a Greek Catholic, a Moslem and a Druse. The majority of the religions and sects of Syria are represented in "the Mountain." Isolated groups of Moslems, both Sannis and Metwali Sbiabs, with a few mountain Beduin, occur in the southern district of Shaf, Dear Zahleh, and in Kesrawan, while isolated Hormil is mainly inhabited by Metwalis. Shof is the centre of the Lebanon Druses, who are also represented in the central district of Metn and in Jezzin in the extreme south. To turn to the Christian sects, the northern districts, with the im portant exception of Kura, & Greek Orthodox stronghold, are almost entirely inhabited by Maronites, Zahleh is predominantly Greek Catholic, and in the southern provinces the sects are mixed, the Maronites being rather more numerous than the Orthodox Greeks, while small groups of Protestants occur bere and there, usually in the neighbourhood of mission stations. No census having been taken since 1862, it impossible to give more than an approximate estimate of the present population of the province. According to the best-informed autborities, tbe Maronites number about 220,000, the Druses 60,000, and the Orthodox Greeks some 45,000, the balance of from 60.000 to 70,000 souls being mainly composed of Greek Catholics and Sunni and Metwali Moslems,

Like most mountaineers, the peasants, who constitute the great majority of the population, are a decidedly attractive race. Physically strong, well-made, and often good looking, they are mentally a shrewd, sharp-witted folk, with an intelligence that is more Buropean-that is, more ratiocinative and controlled to a greater extent by conscious logical processes-than that of the average uneducated or half-educat ed Egyptian, whose pind never seems to have room for more than a few fixed quasi-instinctive ideas wbich he may attempt to defend, but at which he seldom seems to arrive, with the aid of reason. Politically unstable and inclined to petty intrigue, as opportunist as most of their neighbours, still somewhat deficient in moral courage, regarding local affairs too often from & sectarian or personal standpoint, their civic qualities are still rudimentary, though better developed than those of certain other Oriental races. In enterprise, courage, self-respect, and freedom from petty crime they are far superior to the Egyptian; but what most impresses the visitor from Egypt is their respect for women, whose influence on the family life of the people is very marked both among Christians and Druses. A girl may travel alone through the most solitary districts of the Mountain" without fear of harm, and per contra the sight of a laden woman staggering along in the dost behind her lord, who rides comfortably on an ass, common enough in the Nile Valley, is extremely rare, if not unknown, among the Lebanese.

It would be tedious and unprofitable to describe the civil war of 1860, which was simply the culmination of an ancient quarrel between the closely-knit Druse community led by the powerful families of Jumblat and Arslan and tbe less cohesive Maronites, direct ed and often led by their numerous and powerful clergy. The conflict was marked by numerous terrible incidents, such as the sack of Zahleh and the massacre at Dêr el Kamar ; but it may be noted that the Druses, if ruthless in battle, abstained from inflicting any insult or harm on women and children, the more brutal outrages that disgraced the struggle being the work of Turkish troops and of bands of fanatical Moslems from the vilayets of Beirut and Damascus. The civil war and the savage antiChristian ontbreaks in the vilayets caused the intervention of the Powers, which resulted in granting of administrative autonomy to the Lebanon. Though deprived of its natural outlets to the sea and shorn of some of its most fertile areas, the new province secured the inestimable advantage of being guaranteed against direct Turkish interference or administration. Its constitution, as framed in the Organic Law of 1861-6, its revised version of 1864, may be very briefly summarized.

The province is administered by an irremovable Christian Governor appointed for a period of five years and directly dependent upon the Porte. He possesses full administrative powers, save in loyal finance, is responsible for the collection of taxes and the maintence of public order, and the appointment of administrative and executive officials, including Judges of first instance and appeal. He also convokes

the council known as the Mejlis el Idarah. This body is composed of 12 representatives of the seven administrative districts, or kaima kamliks, of "the Mountain" chosen from the dominant seot or seots of each district. Thus Kara is represented by an Orthodox Greek, Zahleh by a Greek Catholic, Shaf by a Druse and a Moslem. The members are elected by the sheikhs of the villages for a period of six years, four members retiring every two years with the right to re-election. The functions of the council are consultative and financial; the latter are of very considerable importance, for the Mejlis el Idareh is, to all intents and purposes, an inde pendent department of finance, solely responsible for the framing of the Budget, the imposition of taxes, infine, for the entire control of the revenue and expenditure. In financial matters its word is law, and, though Naoum Pasha shortly after his appointment as Ambassador obtained the permission of the Porte and the Powers to dismiss every member of the council on the ground of its improper interference with elections, there are obvious reasons against the frequent adoption of so drastic a measure. The administrative unit is the Nah ieh, or village commune, under a sheikh elected by the inhabitants, dependent on the mudirieh, or subdistrict, which is in turn dependent on the kaymakamlik, or administrative district. The kaimakans are appointed by the Governor, the Medjis by the Governor in theory on the recommendation of the kaimakam. The electors of the Mejlis el Idareh are the sheikhs of the village communes of each district, who also possess the power to try petty cases of misdemeanour, &c, and to impose fines not exceeding 200 piastres, their judicial functions resembling those of justices of the peace. Crimes are dealt with by the Courts of first instance and appeal, in which the principle of representation by communities is followed in all “mixed" cases--that is, cases in which the parties are of a different religion or sect.

div.head: A CASE OF INTEREST TO WOMEN
div.p: 15, Milier Street
Coatbridge Scotland.

It is many years ago now since I was first taken with kidney trouble. It began with a dull, grinding pain in the small of my back, bat after a while there were sharp, sudden pangs of pain, which nearly brought me down, and these were followed by other symptoms of kidney trouble, especially gravel, and great pain in passing water.

During pregnancy, the pains were much harder to bear, and just before the birth of my last child there was complete stoppage, which alarmed me very much. My limbs swelled up, and my eyesight was affected. I used to get such pains in the head that I hardly knew what to do with myself.

Doctors and medicine alike failed to give me any relief, but at last I have found help in Doan's Backache Kidney Pills. They have been & real blessing to me, and I will always say 80; nothing has ever given me such ease. Doan's Pills have strengthened my back, and have made me feel better in many ways. Indeed, I can truthfully say that by their occasional use I keep in better health than I was for years before.

Some months later, Mrs. Foster said: "I was grateful for the good Doan's Pills did me when I told you about it some months ago, but how much more grateful I feel now that I can tell you it is a lasting cure! There has been no return of my serious kidney and bladder disorders since Kidney relieved me.
"It is my wish that you make this widely known, so that others suffering as I used to, may know how to get well."

Such distressing symptoms as irregular action of the heart, violent, thumping beats, poor circulation of the blood, cold hands and feet, strained breathing, fainting fits, and dizzy spells, are generally to be traced to the kidneys; seldom is there anything the matter with the heart itself, and when the kidneys are cured the heart troubles also will be cured. If, however these disorders are neglected, dropsical symptoms, such as puffy eyes and swollen ankles and limbs, will appear, and the body will gradually fill with water.
Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T.per box.

div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways.
div.p: Goods may be booked from this Company's system of nearly 1000 kilometers of line in the Delta to any stations on the Egyptain State Railways and the Helouan Line.
Public Telegraph Messages are also accepted at many stations.
For further information apply to the Company's Offices at Cairo, Alexandria, Tantah, Zagazig, Damanhour or Saïda Zenah
